# The Dominant 7th Chord in G (Shape: A)

The Dominant 7th chord is a four-note chord that is built by combining the root (G), major third (B), perfect fifth (D), and minor seventh (F) of the G major scale. When played in the A shape on the guitar, the notes are arranged as follows:

- G (root)
- B (major third)
- D (perfect fifth)
- F (minor seventh)

## Intervals:
- Root (G) to Major Third (B): A major third interval
- Root (G) to Perfect Fifth (D): A perfect fifth interval
- Root (G) to Minor Seventh (F): A minor seventh interval

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The Dominant 7th chord is commonly used in jazz, blues, funk, and rock music genres. It has a strong and unresolved sound due to the presence of the minor seventh interval. This chord adds tension and energy to a progression, often leading to resolution back to the tonic chord.

## Songs that Use the Dominant 7th in G (Shape: A)
1. "Sweet Home Chicago" by Robert Johnson
2. "Stormy Monday" by T-Bone Walker
3. "Crazy Little Thing Called Love" by Queen
